subSections.title: Alternative forms
subSections.text:
* In modern {{w|Written Chinese|Chinese scripts}}, the radical component on the left is written {{l|mul|糹}} (three dots below <small>{{l|mul|幺}}</small>).
* In Japanese {{w|kanji}} and Korean {{w|hanja}}, the radical component on the left is written {{l|mul|糸}} (<small>{{l|mul|小}}</small> below <small>{{l|mul|幺}}</small> but the middle stroke of <small>{{l|mul|小}}</small> is written with a {{l|mul|丨}} vertical stroke without bottom hook), which is the historical form found in the {{w|Kangxi dictionary}}.
* In {{w|traditional Chinese}} and Korean {{w|hanja}}, the <font size=4. lang=zh-hant>[[及#Translingual|及]]</font> component on the right contains {{l|mul|又}}, which is the historical form found in the {{w|Kangxi dictionary}}.
* In mainland China (for the traditional form based on {{w|Xin Zixing}} ({{w2|zh|新字形}})), Japanese {{w|kanji}} and Vietnamese [[Nôm]], the <font size=4. lang=zh-hans>[[及#Translingual|及]]</font> component on the right does not contain {{l|mul|又}} and is written in 3 strokes ({{l|mul|丿}} followed by ⿱{{l|mul|[[乛]][[乛]]}} and {{l|mul|㇏}}).
